I notice that there appears to be a correlation between a baseball player’s value, or WAR, and their average salary throughout their 10-year contract. I wonder why those who deviate from the typical range depicted in the graph do so. Some examples include Albert Pujois, who does not earn a lot (less $15,000,000) despite having the second-highest WAR, and Ryan Howard, getting paid $25,000,000 for having a negative WAR.
This graph relates to my community and me in that we can generalize these findings to demonstrate that, typically, our contribution to a team dictates our payoff. Given that it is possible that people in my current classes and social circle can end up working together with each other or with me as part of a team later down the line, it is important we each positively contribute to project efforts.
Catchy Headline: “WAR: Does Your Contract Value Your Contributions to the Team?”

name: Liam Quach
comment info:
What I notice:

The graph compares the average yearly WAR (Wins Above Replacement) and average yearly salary during 10-year MLB contracts.
There is a clear trend that players with higher average yearly WAR tend to earn higher average yearly salaries.
However, the relationship is not perfectly linear. Some players like Mike Trout stand out as having an exceptionally high WAR relative to their salary.
There also seems to be more variability in salaries at the higher end of the WAR spectrum.

What I wonder:

What other factors besides on-field performance (WAR) impact player salaries? 

Are teams getting good value from these mega long-term contracts, or do they tend to backfire as players age? Comparing salary to WAR over the full contract would be informative.

How has this relationship between WAR and salary for top contracts evolved over time as analytics and player valuations have advanced?

Impact on the sport and fanbases:

As teams commit huge sums to top stars, it could impact competitive balance, roster construction, and fan perception if highly paid players underperform.

However, building around contracted superstars allows fanbases to have long-term attachment to franchise icons.

As younger stars like Juan Soto sign massive deals, it will be fascinating to see how the market evolves and if they live up to expectations.

Potential headline: "MLB's big money bets: The relationship between star players' production and pay in an era of mega contracts"
